qas.question: How many men did the Russians lose after three hours?
Which river did the allies come across the Russian Army?
How many hours did it take to force the Russians away during the attack?
How many allies were lost during the battle?
Which way did the Russians believe they should have traveled?

context: The landing was north of Sevastopol, so the Russians had arrayed their army in expectation of a direct attack. The allies advanced and on the morning of 20 September came up to the <a1_0>Alma river<a1_0/> and the whole Russian army. The position was strong, but after <a2_0>three hours<a2_0/>,:424 the frontal attack had driven the Russians out of their dug in positions with losses of <a0_0>6000 men<a0_0/>. The Battle of the Alma had <a3_0>3,300<a3_0/> Allied losses. Failing to pursue the retreating forces was one of many strategic errors made during the war, and the Russians themselves noted that had they pressed <a4_0>south<a4_0/> that day they would have easily captured Sevastopol.
